column4: my xubuntu system here has it's filesystem seperated into 6 partitions :D
how it helps? I can see /root and /Home and /swap but 6???
my /var /tmp and /home are seperate, which means I can use different block sizes :D
block sizes are different because of different partition sizes or you set them up manually, file system is ext3 or reiser?
can you give me your values as examples? I was always going with defaults but would be nice to experiment and see if it makes it faster or more space efficient?
generally the smaller the block size the more 'efficient', minus the extra overhead for storing the file info. smaller blocks = better for smaller files
the more useful reason that I seperated was that if I loose a filesystem for some reason, it isn't crippling
and seperate journals for each means move journal coverage overall :P
small is relative 1kB file or 100kB is still small? And I'm not guru in journalized files systems so if partition fails data is corrupted hmm dont feel that last one
generally don't worry about block size. It's one of those things where "If you don't know what it's for, you don't need it"

as far as journal... the journal on each FS can only store so many 'transactions' (writes, erases, etc) - having a seperate journal for frequently used filesystems (/var) means that more journal is available on /home for instance.
remember dealing with it since first 2GB disks back in DOS times so I know a bit. Just dont know how small/bi file size changed since than
poke around with 'ls -lah /directory' to figure out average filesizes
regardless of filesize, a file is stored in whole blocks (so if you have a 64kb file on a system with 16kb blocks, that file uses 4 blocks. a 67 kb file would take 5.)

yes this I remember since DOS times hehe. But about lots of transactions - what level of files system usage justifies such trick? server or even single workstation can benefit? And what you think about reiser fs? it supposed to be better and faster than ext(s) is it true?
if you use a modern FS (even NTFS) it journals EVERYTHING
